name: 1607_A. Linear Keyboard
description:
You are given a keyboard that consists of 26 keys. The keys are arranged sequentially in one row in a certain order. Each key corresponds to a unique lowercase Latin letter.

You have to type the word s on this keyboard. It also consists only of lowercase Latin letters.

To type a word, you need to type all its letters consecutively one by one. To type each letter you must position your hand exactly over the corresponding key and press it.

Moving the hand between the keys takes time which is equal to the absolute value of the difference between positions of these keys (the keys are numbered from left to right). No time is spent on pressing the keys and on placing your hand over the first letter of the word.

For example, consider a keyboard where the letters from 'a' to 'z' are arranged in consecutive alphabetical order. The letters 'h', 'e', 'l' and 'o' then are on the positions 8, 5, 12 and 15, respectively. Therefore, it will take |5 - 8| + |12 - 5| + |12 - 12| + |15 - 12| = 13 units of time to type the word "hello". 

Determine how long it will take to print the word s.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain descriptions of the test cases.

The first line of a description contains a keyboard — a string of length 26, which consists only of lowercase Latin letters. Each of the letters from 'a' to 'z' appears exactly once on the keyboard.

The second line of the description contains the word s. The word has a length from 1 to 50 letters inclusive and consists of lowercase Latin letters.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to the test case is the minimal time it takes to type the word s on the given keyboard.

Example

Input


5
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
hello
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
i
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
codeforces
qwertyuiopasdfghjklzxcvbnm
qqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqq
qwertyuiopasdfghjklzxcvbnm
abacaba


Output


13
0
68
0
74

prompt:
You are given a keyboard that consists of 26 keys set up in sequence in one row in a particular order, where each key corresponds to a unique lowercase Latin letter, and you have to type the word s on this keyboard, which consists only of lowercase Latin letters. To type each letter you must position your hand exactly over the corresponding key and press it.

Moving the hand between the keys takes time which is equal to the absolute value of the difference between positions of these keys (the keys are numbered from left to right), and no time is spent on pressing the keys and on placing your hand over the first letter of the word. For example, consider a keyboard where the letters from 'a' to 'z' are arranged in consecutive alphabetical order; the letters 'h', 'e', 'l' and 'o' then are on the positions 8, 5, 12 and 15, respectively, so it will take |5 - 8| + |12 - 5| + |12 - 12| + |15 - 12| = 13 units of time to type the word "hello". 

Determine how long it will take to print the word s. Remember to consider the initial positioning of the hand before typing the first letter as part of the time calculation.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain descriptions of the test cases.

The first line of a description contains a keyboard — a string of length 26, which consists only of lowercase Latin letters. Each of the letters from 'a' to 'z' appears exactly once on the keyboard.

The second line of the description contains the word s. The word has a length from 1 to 50 letters inclusive and consists of lowercase Latin letters.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to the test case is the minimal time it takes to type the word s on the given keyboard.

Example

Input


5
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
hello
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
i
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
codeforces
qwertyuiopasdfghjklzxcvbnm
qqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqq
qwertyuiopasdfghjklzxcvbnm
abacaba


Output


13
0
68
0
74
repair_prompt:
You are given a keyboard that consists of 26 keys set up in sequence in one row in a particular order, where each key corresponds to a unique lowercase Latin letter, and you have to type the word s on this keyboard, which consists only of lowercase Latin letters. To type each letter you must position your hand exactly over the corresponding key and press it.

Moving the hand between the keys takes time which is equal to the absolute value of the difference between positions of these keys (the keys are numbered from left to right), and no time is spent on pressing the keys and on placing your hand over the first letter of the word. For example, consider a keyboard where the letters from 'a' to 'z' are arranged in consecutive alphabetical order; the letters 'h', 'e', 'l' and 'o' then are on the positions 8, 5, 12 and 15, respectively, so it will take |5 - 8| + |12 - 5| + |12 - 12| + |15 - 12| = 13 units of time to type the word "hello". 

Determine how long it will take to print the word s. Remember to consider the initial positioning of the hand before typing the first letter as part of the time calculation.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain descriptions of the test cases.

The first line of a description contains a keyboard — a string of length 26, which consists only of lowercase Latin letters. Each of the letters from 'a' to 'z' appears exactly once on the keyboard.

The second line of the description contains the word s. The word has a length from 1 to 50 letters inclusive and consists of lowercase Latin letters.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to the test case is the minimal time it takes to type the word s on the given keyboard.

-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.
Example

Input


5

Write a main() function and use input() function to read input from stdin

from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    """
    Calculate the time required to type a given word on a specific keyboard layout.

    Args:
        keyboard (str): A string representing the keyboard layout where each character is a unique lowercase Latin letter.
        word (str): The word to be typed, consisting of lowercase Latin letters.

    Returns:
        int: The total time required to type the word.
    """
    # Create a dictionary to map each letter to its position on the keyboard
    keyboard_positions = {}
    for index, letter in enumerate(keyboard):
        keyboard_positions[letter] = index

    # Initialize the total time to 0
    total_time = 0

    # Calculate the time for each consecutive pair of letters in the word
    for i in range(len(word) - 1):
        current_letter = word[i]
        next_letter = word[i + 1]
        current_position = keyboard_positions[current_letter]
        next_position = keyboard_positions[next_letter]
        total_time += abs(current_position - next_position)

    return total_time

# Read the number of test cases
t = int(input())

# Process each test case
for _ in range(t):
    keyboard = input().strip()
    word = input().strip()
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    """
    Calculate the time required to type a given word on a specific keyboard layout.

    Args:
        keyboard (str): A string representing the keyboard layout where each character is a unique lowercase Latin letter.
        word (str): The word to be typed, consisting of lowercase Latin letters.

    Returns:
        int: The total time required to type the word.
    """
    # Create a dictionary to map each letter to its position on the keyboard
    keyboard_positions = {char: index for index, char in enumerate(keyboard)}

    # Initialize the total time to 0
    total_time = 0

    # Calculate the time to type the first letter (no movement time)
    previous_position = 0  # Start at position 0 (assuming hand starts here)

    # Iterate over each letter in the word
    for letter in word:
        current_position = keyboard_positions[letter]
        # Calculate the time to move from the previous position to the current position
        time_to_move = abs(current_position - previous_position)
        # Add the movement time to the total time
        total_time += time_to_move
        # Update the previous position to the current position
        previous_position = current_position

    return total_time

# Read input from stdin
t = int(input())
for _ in range(t):
    keyboard = input()
    word = input()
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    """
    Calculate the time required to type a given word on a specific keyboard layout.

    Args:
        keyboard (str): A string representing the keyboard layout where each character is a unique lowercase Latin letter.
        word (str): The word to be typed, consisting of lowercase Latin letters.

    Returns:
        int: The total time required to type the word.
    """
    # Create a dictionary to map each letter to its position on the keyboard
    keyboard_positions = {char: idx for idx, char in enumerate(keyboard)}

    # Initialize the total time to 0
    total_time = 0

    # Calculate the time to type the first letter (no movement time)
    previous_position = keyboard_positions[word[0]]

    # Iterate over the word starting from the second letter
    for letter in word[1:]:
        current_position = keyboard_positions[letter]
        # Add the absolute difference in positions to the total time
        total_time += abs(current_position - previous_position)
        # Update the previous position to the current position
        previous_position = current_position

    return total_time

# Read from stdin
import sys

# Read the number of test cases
t = int(sys.stdin.readline().strip())

# Loop through each test case
for _ in range(t):
    # Read the keyboard layout
    keyboard = sys.stdin.readline().strip()
    # Read the word to type
    word = sys.stdin.readline().strip()
    # Calculate the typing time
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    # Output the result
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    """
    Calculate the time required to type a word on a given keyboard.

    Args:
        keyboard (str): A string representing the layout of the keyboard.
        word (str): The word to be typed.

    Returns:
        int: The total time required to type the word.
    """
    # Create a dictionary to map each letter to its position on the keyboard
    keyboard_positions = {}
    for index, letter in enumerate(keyboard):
        keyboard_positions[letter] = index

    # Initialize the total time to 0
    total_time = 0

    # Calculate the time for each letter in the word
    for i in range(1, len(word)):
        current_pos = keyboard_positions[word[i]]
        previous_pos = keyboard_positions[word[i - 1]]
        total_time += abs(current_pos - previous_pos)

    return total_time

# Read from stdin
import sys

# Read the number of test cases
t = int(sys.stdin.readline().strip())

# Process each test case
for _ in range(t):
    keyboard = sys.stdin.readline().strip()
    word = sys.stdin.readline().strip()
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    # Create a dictionary to map each letter to its position on the keyboard
    position_map = {}
    
    # Initialize the total typing time
    total_time = 0
    
    # Populate the position_map with the positions of each letter on the keyboard
    for index, letter in enumerate(keyboard):
        position_map[letter] = index
    
    # Calculate the typing time for the word
    for i in range(len(word) - 1):
        current_letter = word[i]
        next_letter = word[i + 1]
        current_position = position_map[current_letter]
        next_position = position_map[next_letter]
        total_time += abs(current_position - next_position)
    
    return total_time

# Read the number of test cases
t = int(input())

# Process each test case
for _ in range(t):
    # Read the keyboard layout
    keyboard = input()
    # Read the word to type
    word = input()
    # Calculate the typing time for the word
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    # Output the calculated typing time
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    # Create a dictionary to map each key to its position on the keyboard
    key_positions = {}
    for index, key in enumerate(keyboard):
        key_positions[key] = index
    
    # Initialize the total time with the time to position the hand at the first letter
    total_time = 0
    
    # Calculate the time to type the word based on the positions of consecutive letters
    for i in range(len(word) - 1):
        current_key = word[i]
        next_key = word[i + 1]
        total_time += abs(key_positions[current_key] - key_positions[next_key])
    
    return total_time

# Read the number of test cases from stdin
import sys
t = int(sys.stdin.readline().strip())

for _ in range(t):
    # Read the keyboard layout
    keyboard = sys.stdin.readline().strip()
    # Read the word to be typed
    word = sys.stdin.readline().strip()
    # Calculate and print the result
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    # Create a dictionary to map each letter to its position on the keyboard
    keyboard_positions = {}
    for index, letter in enumerate(keyboard):
        keyboard_positions[letter] = index
    
    # Initialize the time to 0
    total_time = 0
    
    # Calculate the time to type the first letter
    first_letter_position = keyboard_positions[word[0]]
    
    # Iterate over the word to calculate the total time
    for i in range(1, len(word)):
        current_letter_position = keyboard_positions[word[i]]
        previous_letter_position = keyboard_positions[word[i - 1]]
        total_time += abs(current_letter_position - previous_letter_position)
    
    return total_time

# Read the number of test cases
t = int(input())

# Process each test case
for _ in range(t):
    keyboard = input()
    word = input()
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    print(result)

## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    # Create a dictionary to map each letter to its position on the keyboard
    keyboard_positions = {}
    for index, letter in enumerate(keyboard):
        keyboard_positions[letter] = index
    
    # Initialize the time to 0
    time = 0
    
    # Calculate the time to type the word
    for i in range(len(word) - 1):
        current_position = keyboard_positions[word[i]]
        next_position = keyboard_positions[word[i + 1]]
        time += abs(current_position - next_position)
    
    return time

# Read the number of test cases
t = int(input())

# Process each test case
for _ in range(t):
    keyboard = input()
    word = input()
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    # Create a dictionary to map each letter to its position on the keyboard
    position_map = {}
    for index, letter in enumerate(keyboard):
        position_map[letter] = index
    
    # Initialize the time to position the hand over the first letter
    total_time = abs(position_map[word[0]])
    
    # Calculate the time for each consecutive letter
    for i in range(1, len(word)):
        current_position = position_map[word[i]]
        previous_position = position_map[word[i - 1]]
        total_time += abs(current_position - previous_position)
    
    return total_time

# Read the number of test cases
t = int(input())

# Process each test case
for _ in range(t):
    keyboard = input()
    word = input()
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    # Create a dictionary to map each letter to its position on the keyboard
    keyboard_positions = {}
    for index, letter in enumerate(keyboard):
        keyboard_positions[letter] = index
    
    # Initialize the total time with the time to position the hand at the first letter
    total_time = 0
    
    # Calculate the time to type the word based on the positions of the letters
    for i in range(len(word) - 1):
        current_letter = word[i]
        next_letter = word[i + 1]
        total_time += abs(keyboard_positions[current_letter] - keyboard_positions[next_letter])
    
    return total_time

# Read the number of test cases
t = int(input())

# Process each test case
for _ in range(t):
    keyboard = input()
    word = input()
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    print(result)

requirement analysis:

The challenge lies in accurately mapping each letter's position on the keyboard and calculating the time based on the positions of consecutive letters. The solution should be efficient and capable of handling a large number of test cases within a reasonable time frame.

examples:
Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain descriptions of the test cases.

The first line of a description contains a keyboard — a string of length 26, which consists only of lowercase Latin letters. Each of the letters from 'a' to 'z' appears exactly once on the keyboard.

The second line of the description contains the word s. The word has a length from 1 to 50 letters inclusive and consists of lowercase Latin letters.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to the test case is the minimal time it takes to type the word s on the given keyboard.

Example

Input


5
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
hello
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
i
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
codeforces
qwertyuiopasdfghjklzxcvbnm
qqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqq
qwertyuiopasdfghjklzxcvbnm
abacaba


Output


13
0
68
0
74
